session.name: Contributed Orals: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operation

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: On-Demand Beam Route and RF Parameter Switching System for Time-Sharing of a Linac for X-ray Free-Electron Laser as an Injector to a 4th-Generation Synchrotron Radiation Source
paper.abstract: We have an upgrade plan of the SPring-8 storage ring to provide much more brilliant X-rays with a low-emittance electron beam. Since the upgraded ring requires a low-emittance injection beam, we are planning to timeshare the linac of the X-ray free electron laser (XFEL) facility, SACLA, as an injector for the upgraded ring. The SACLA linac delivers low-emittance and short-bunch electron beams to two XFEL beamlines with a 60 Hz repetition rate. The beam route is right now equally changed by a kicker magnet at a switchyard. The beam parameter is also optimized for each XFEL beamline by changing RF parameters pulse-by-pulse with simple software at this moment*. Since the number of beam injection shots to the storage ring is much less frequent than XFEL shots, one of the XFEL shots must be overridden by an injection with on-demand basis. In addition, the beam quality, such as 1 mm mrad normalized emittance, 10 fs bunch length and 10 kA peak current, must be maintained not to deteriorate the XFEL performance. Therefore, we have developed an on-demand beam route and RF parameter switching system with sufficient speed, precision and reliability. A beam route data is transmitted to each accelerator unit by a reflective memory network, and special software changes the parameters of each accelerator unit pulse-by-pulse according to the received data. We tested the on-demand switching system at a test bench and the SACLA linac. The beam parameters were appropriately controlled with a negligible failure rate. The user service of the beam injection from SACLA to SPring-8 is scheduled in 2020 and the on-demand switching system is almost ready for the time-sharing operation of multiple XFEL beamlines and a SPring-8 injection.
paper.footnote: * T. Hara et al., Phys. Rev. Accel. Beams 21, 040701 (2018).

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: Different Versions of Cryogenic Current Comparators with Magnetic Core for Beam Current Measurements
paper.abstract: For more than 20 years Cryogenic Current Comparators (CCC) are used to measure the current of charged particle beams with low intensity (nA-range). The device was first established at GSI in Darmstadt and was improved over the past two decades by the cooperation of institutes in Jena, GSI and CERN. The improved versions differ in material parameters and electronics to increase the resolution and in dimensions in order to meet the requirements of the respective application. The device allows non-destructive measurements of the charged particle beam current. The azimuthal magnetic field which is generated by the beam current is detected by low temperature Superconducting Quantum Interference Device (SQUID) current sensors. A complex shaped superconductor cooled down to 4.2 K is used as magnetic shielding and a high permeability core serves as flux concentrator. Three versions of the CCC shall be presented in this work: (1) GSI-Pb-CCC which was running at GSI Darmstadt in a transfer line, (2) CERN-Nb-CCC currently installed in the Antiproton Decelerator at CERN and (3) GSI-Nb-CCC-XD which will be operating in the CRYRING at GSI 2019. Noise, signal and drift measurements were performed in the Cryo-Detector Lab at the University of Jena.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: A Remote-Controlled Robot-Car in the TPS Tunnel
paper.abstract: A remote-controlled robot-car named ¿PhotonBot¿ was put into the TPS accelerator tunnel and is equipped with a 360 degrees LiDAR for SLAM and navigation, two cameras for perception and first-person view, and a thermal imaging system. The robot can be remotely controlled and can send data to a remote PC through Wi-Fi. With SLAM, it can go more freely without being restricted to a designated path. In order to ensure it can work continuously, there is a wireless charging station in case of a low battery.

abstract_log.comments:
Technical comments: The devices in the robots may be vulnerable against radiation. Is it no problem in photon sources like TPS? Does authors estimate the life-time of the robot against the radiation.
Why the height is extended only to 1100 mm, while the beam line is at the height of 1350 mm.
Fig. 2-5: Difficult to exactly understand the meaning of the figure. It is better to put the explanation in the figure. For example, what is the meaning of the many red arrows in Fig. 3, where is the robot and which is the direction of the camera in Fig. 4, what the blue area in Fig. 5 represents?
Fig. 11-14: It is helpful to put a bar graph in the figure to show which color in the contour plots represent what temperature.
If there are any references for the robot monitor in the accelerator tunnel, the authors should include them in the references.
Typos or comments for sentences. P. 1: Put the email address on the left footnote according to the JACoW template.
All text: Improve English in the article by native.
All figure captions: Wright the figure caption in full justification style.
All text: Put space before the unit ¿mA¿.
P. 1 left: LiDar may not a familiar word for many readers. Describe the meaning of the abbreviation, when it first appears in the text, like Laser Imaging Detection and Ranging (LiDar).
P. 1: It is better to write the reference for ROBOTIS in the text not in the figure caption. It means ¿The PhotonBot is developed from a model called ¿Turtlebot3 waffle-Pi¿, which is a product from the company ROBOTIS [1].¿
All text: It is better to use ¿∘¿instead of ¿degrees¿.
P. 1 left: Change ¿ROS (Robot Operating System)¿ to ¿Robot Operating System (ROS)¿
P. 1 right: Change ¿0.26m/s.[1]¿ to ¿0.26m/s [1].¿.
P. 1 right: Change ¿some basic operations:¿ to ¿some basic operations.¿.
P. 1 right: Describe the meaning of ¿RViz¿.
Fig. 2 caption: Change "interact¿ to ¿Interact¿
Fig. 2 caption: Change ¿Point Operation¿ to ¿`Poit operation¿
P. 2 right: Put the space before ¿mm¿.
P. 2 left: Change ¿a few modifications had to be made:¿ to ¿ a few modifications had to be made.¿.
P. 2 Left: Remove one of double spaces between ¿to¿ and ¿the¿ in ¿which brings the sensors closer to the main accelerator components (Fig. 6).¿
Fig. 6 caption: Put a period.
P. 2 left: Put a space before ¿mAh¿.
Fig. 8 caption: Remove the reference ¿[2]¿. There is the same expression in the text. It¿s enough.
Fig. 8 caption: Put a period.
P. 3 right: Write the text in full justification style.
Fig. 10-14 caption: Use capital for the first letter in the captions.

abstract_log.comments:
Technical comments: The manuscript was improved from the technical point of view. The remaining comment is the following. The author added the bar graph in Fig. 11-14. However, there is no scale. I meant that it would be helpful for readers to understand the temperature value from the figure. For example, putting the maximum and minimum temperature value on the bar graph would be helpful.
Typos or comments for sentences. The length of the manuscript exceeds the page limit (up to 3 pages). If there are many references, some of them can be carried over an extra page. Consider making the manuscript shorter.
P. 1 left: Describe the meaning of the abbreviation, when it first appears in the text, not in the abstract. Maybe in the abstract only the abbreviation is no problem. Write like ¿Laser Imaging Detection and Ranging (LiDar)¿ not ¿LiDAR (Laser Imaging Detection and Ranging)¿.
P. 2 left: Put the space before m in (x = 1m, y = 1m).
P. 1 right to P2. left: Change ¿RViz (ROS visualization)¿ to ¿ROS visualization (RViz)¿.
Fig. 6 caption: Put a period.
Reference: There are strange TAB spaces in the references.

abstract_log.comments:
The author responds to some of the comments. But there are still some points to be corrected.
[Technical comments]
The author added the bar graph in Fig. 11-14. However, there is no scale. I meant that it would be helpful for readers to understand the temperature value from the figure. For example, putting the maximum and minimum temperature value on the bar graph would be helpful.
[Typos or comments for sentences.]
P. 2 left: Describe the meaning of the abbreviation when it first appears in the text, not in the abstract. Write like ¿Laser Imaging Detection and Ranging (LiDar)¿ not ¿LiDAR (Laser Imaging Detection and Ranging)¿.
P1-3: The author uses Lidar and LiDAR. Please standardize one of them.
P. 1 right to P2. left: Change ¿RViz (ROS visualization)¿ to ¿ROS visualization (RViz)¿.
Reference: There are strange TAB spaces in the references.
